Mentarian Vs. Man

Improving Hell
Soph-Frosh Hell Week proved to
be too much of a good thing. Unofficially begun two days before it was
scheduled to open, its spirit died a
day before it was scheduled to close.
As a consequence the greased ball
rush, which was to provide a grand
finale, was a fiasco.
In the past two years, we have had
the opportunity to witness the two
extreme forms which Hell Week may
take. Last year the activities were
cut to a minimum. This year it was
everybody for himself and the devil
take the hindmost, with the "hindmost" usually going into Freshman
pond.
Having observed the comparative
merits of the two systems we have
come to the conclusion that the one
is too tame, and the other, too extreme. So we offer a plan which we
hope will satisfy both the desires of
the avaricious leftist wing of pantspuller-off-ers and the conservative
group which prefers to keep its pants
on.
This year, hostilities were started
too late in the season. Many students
were unable to join the conflict because of the press of work which
begins near the end of the semester.
The best time to schedule the fight
is during the third week of April
when there is a lull between quarterly examinations and the preparations
for the spurt which precedes final
exams.
The season should extend over a
period of three days—during which
all afternoon classes should be suspended. This period will be long
enough to let everyone get his fill of
kidnapping. fiehting, and pond water.
and short enough to Preserve interest. With fighting going on in the

MANIFESTO

The Mentarian life is as far removed from the Human life as the
Human from the Dog's or, the Dog's
from that of the very lowest life.
There are, roughly, four manners of
living in the Animal Kingdom;—first,
the pure patterned instinct; second,
instinct plus acquired traits; third,
intelligent acquisitive behaviour; and
fourth, the Mentarian non-acquisitive
mode as above described. The difference between the amoeba and the dog

To satisfy the advocates of rugged
and ragged individualism, one afternoon could be designated as Pond
Day, during which there would be
informal fighting around the pond.
Speaking from two-fold experience,
we know that a good ducking will
not dampen enthusiasm. On the contrary, it will make one all the more
desirous of giving back just as much
as he gets.
Although many people condemn
Hell Week as being babyish, primitive and purposeless, we cannot
agree with them. We think that this
battle does more to promote goodwill, enthusiasm, and spirit than any
other activity on the campus. The
Hopkins undergraduate schools are
not so well supplied with school spirit that they can afford to forego this
colorful institution.

supply,—so the Mentarians indiscriminately eat the Human Dullards
with their satire, being restrained
only by the consideration that such
Dullards are after all the source of
their remuneration.
But any antagonism between Mentarians and Men lies even deeper than
Throughout history, it has
that.
been the Men themselves who have
taken the initiative. They trampled
down the pride of a Jonathan Swift,
kept him groveling for twenty years
as a lacky to insolent Bores, and let
him die, a terrible, insane death. They
laughed at Pope, taunted Machiavelli,
poisoned Socrates. For his thoughts,
they burned Bruno; for his science,
they jailed Roger Bacon; and for his
quiet wisdom, they stoned Leonardo
da Vinci. It is certainly no mere
fantasy to state that Mentarians are
not only a breed apart—but are separated by an uncrossable gulf of
hatred.
III. Progress
Men have fooled themselves into believing that they've been rapidly becoming greater and greater. Haven't
they telephones, airplanes, and almost
complete tyranny over nature herSure, but look closer—look
self?
again at this splendid civilization—
the result of centuries of avarice.
This triumph of man is nothing but
a mound of comfort elevated by the
seat of somewhat gifted savages. Is
the 20th Century savage superior to
the Pre-Christian savage merely because he sits on more cushions?
There are still wars, murders, and
persecution, bloody as ever. Indeed,
it would seem that Men had not advanced one whit these two thousand
years. Having emerged from the natural state which produced them,
they seem to have stopped evolving
—to have come to a blind alley like
that which the dinosaurs once entered.
Men are threatened with stagnation!

KEMLER
evolving for maybe a billion years in
its blind fashion, finally an end-product, a -Mentarian, becomes aware of
part of that process by which he was
created. And in the hands of the
Mentarians, this knowledge is a wonderful tool.
If Men can no longer progress and
the Mentarians have been failures all
these years, what is wrong? The
point is that life can no longer evolve
blindly. If the Mentarians, the men
of the future, will survive, they must
use the tool which Darwin gave
them.
They must artificially make
plans to save themselves and the
progress of the Animal Kingdom. No
longer does the world see an unconscious evolution. From now on, it
must be a conscious and MILITANT
drive ahead!
IV. The Class Struggle
Since the late Russian Bolshevik
Revolution, there has been in the
United States a general enlistment of
Mentarians in the working-class parties. Sympathy for the exploited is
partly the cause—and also, perhaps,
the assumption that the intellectual
can be a leader or teacher of a revolutionary movement.
It seems that the great movements
of history have been nothing more
than the wholesale violence of groups
of people who themselves have suffered violence. Each group is desperate; each seeks to satisfy its appetites at the others' expense. But an
intellectual leader, a non-acquisitive
bombast—where does he come in?
Can he share the avarice of the mob,
their frenzy, madness, and control
the mass emotion? Napoleon once
said, "The nation must have a head
—a head who is rendered illustrious
by glory, and not by fine phrases and
the talk of idealists." And Napoleon
was a notorious success. In other
words, RETURN the class struggle

Mt. Washington
Downs Jays, 6-1
(Continued from Pagel, Col. 2)
The Jays' strongest department
was undoubtedly the distance event,
which include the half-male, mile, and
two-mile grinds. Scoring 25 out of
27 points, the Black and Blue captured first and second in the two former races and swept all three places
in the longer contest. The Blue Jay
competitors were not extended in any
of these events, and won as they
pleased, not attempting to return
their best possible performances.
Leonard Emmert turned in the best
time, negotiating the two miles in 10
min., 27.4 sec., to lead home Hughes
and Johnson, both Hopkins representatives, by about 200 yards. In the
mile Carl Sholtes and Paul Holtzman
paced each other throughout the race,
with the former trotting across the
line about a foot in front. Sholtes
also secured second in the half, losing
by about the same distance to Eddie
Gray, a graduate student from St.
John's, who now sports the Jay
colors.
Other Blue Jays who performed
well were Jarman, Peppler, and
Jarman returned the
Chancellor.
good time of 26.3 in the 220-yard low
hurdles, defeating two C. U. competitors. Peppler ran an exciting race in
the quarter, battling neck and neck
with Hugel, of the vistors, who retained a small lead to win by a yard.
Chancellor secured a third in the
shotput and was runner-up in the discus, both events being won by Clements, Catholic U. ace.

Improving Hell
Soph-Frosh Hell Week proved to
be too much of a good thing. Unofficially begun two days before it was
scheduled to open, its spirit died a
day before it was scheduled to close.
As a consequence the greased ball
rush, which was to provide a grand
finale, was a fiasco.
In the past two years, we have had
the opportunity to witness the two
extreme forms which Hell Week may
take. Last year the activities were
cut to a minimum. This year it was
everybody for himself and the devil
take the hindmost, with the "hindmost" usually going into Freshman
pond.
Having observed the comparative
merits of the two systems we have
come to the conclusion that the one
is too tame, and the other, too extreme. So we offer a plan which we
hope will satisfy both the desires of
the avaricious leftist wing of pantspuller-off-ers and the conservative
group which prefers to keep its pants
on.
This year, hostilities were started
too late in the season. Many students
were unable to join the conflict because of the press of work which
begins near the end of the semester.
The best time to schedule the fight
is during the third week of April
when there is a lull between quarterly examinations and the preparations
for the spurt which precedes final
exams.
The season should extend over a
period of three days—during which
all afternoon classes should be suspended. This period will be long
enough to let everyone get his fill of

The Mentarian life is as far removed from the Human life as the
Human from the Dog's or, the Dog's
from that of the very lowest life.
There are, roughly, four manners of
living in the Animal Kingdom;—first,
the pure patterned instinct; second,
instinct plus acquired traits; third,
intelligent acquisitive behaviour; and
fourth, the Mentarian non-acquisitive
mode as above described. The difference between the amoeba and the dog

Speaking from two-fold experience,
we know that a good ducking will
not dampen enthusiasm. On the contrary, it will make one all the more
desirous of giving back just as much
as he gets.
Although many people condemn
Hell Week as being babyish, primitive and purposeless, we cannot
agree with them. We think that this
battle does more to promote goodwill, enthusiasm, and spirit than any
other activity on the campus. The
Hopkins undergraduate schools are
not so well supplied with school spirit that they can afford to forego this
colorful institution.

So much for the Dog's attitude. Now

been incorporated among Man's most

But the Mentarian, what does he
think? Here it is found that in almost
the identical way in which Men eat
Cows without the least worry as to

those problems concern their food
supply,—so the Mentarians indiscriminately eat the Human Dullards
with their satire, being restrained
only by the consideration that such
Dullards are after all the source of
their remuneration.
But any antagonism between Mentarians and Men lies even deeper than
Throughout history, it has
that.
been the Men themselves who have
taken the initiative. They trampled
down the pride of a Jonathan Swift,
kept him groveling for twenty years
as a lacky to insolent Bores, and let
him die, a terrible, insane death. They
laughed at Pope, taunted Machiavelli,
poisoned Socrates. For his thoughts,
they burned Bruno; for his science,
they jailed Roger Bacon; and for his
quiet wisdom, they stoned Leonardo
da Vinci. It is certainly no mere
fantasy to state that Mentarians are
not only a breed apart—but are separated by an uncrossable gulf of
hatred.
III. Progress
Men have fooled themselves into believing that they've been rapidly becoming greater and greater. Haven't
they telephones, airplanes, and almost
complete tyranny over nature herSure, but look closer—look
self?
again at this splendid civilization—
the result of centuries of avarice.
This triumph of man is nothing but
a mound of comfort elevated by the
seat of somewhat gifted savages. Is
the 20th Century savage superior to
the Pre-Christian savage merely because he sits on more cushions?
There are still wars, murders, and
persecution, bloody as ever. Indeed,
it would seem that Men had not advanced one whit these two thousand
years. Having emerged from the natural state which produced them,
they seem to have stopped evolving
—to have come to a blind alley like
that which the dinosaurs once entered.
Men are threatened with stagnation!

KEMLER
evolving for maybe a billion years in
its blind fashion, finally an end-product, a -Mentarian, becomes aware of
part of that process by which he was
created. And in the hands of the
Mentarians, this knowledge is a wonderful tool.
If Men can no longer progress and
the Mentarians have been failures all
these years, what is wrong? The
point is that life can no longer evolve
blindly. If the Mentarians, the men
of the future, will survive, they must
use the tool which Darwin gave
them.
They must artificially make
plans to save themselves and the
progress of the Animal Kingdom. No
longer does the world see an unconscious evolution. From now on, it
must be a conscious and MILITANT
drive ahead!
IV. The Class Struggle
Since the late Russian Bolshevik
Revolution, there has been in the
United States a general enlistment of
Mentarians in the working-class parties. Sympathy for the exploited is
partly the cause—and also, perhaps,
the assumption that the intellectual
can be a leader or teacher of a revolutionary movement.
It seems that the great movements
of history have been nothing more
than the wholesale violence of groups
of people who themselves have suffered violence. Each group is desperate; each seeks to satisfy its appetites at the others' expense. But an
intellectual leader, a non-acquisitive
bombast—where does he come in?
Can he share the avarice of the mob,
their frenzy, madness, and control
the mass emotion? Napoleon once
said, "The nation must have a head
—a head who is rendered illustrious
by glory, and not by fine phrases and
the talk of idealists." And Napoleon
was a notorious success. In other
words, RETURN the class struggle

Mt. Washington
Downs Jays, 6-1
(Continued from Pagel, Col. 2)
The Jays' strongest department
was undoubtedly the distance event,
which include the half-male, mile, and
two-mile grinds. Scoring 25 out of
27 points, the Black and Blue captured first and second in the two former races and swept all three places
in the longer contest. The Blue Jay
competitors were not extended in any
of these events, and won as they
pleased, not attempting to return
their best possible performances.
Leonard Emmert turned in the best
time, negotiating the two miles in 10
min., 27.4 sec., to lead home Hughes
and Johnson, both Hopkins representatives, by about 200 yards. In the
mile Carl Sholtes and Paul Holtzman
paced each other throughout the race,
with the former trotting across the
line about a foot in front. Sholtes
also secured second in the half, losing
by about the same distance to Eddie
Gray, a graduate student from St.
John's, who now sports the Jay
colors.
Other Blue Jays who performed
well were Jarman, Peppler, and
Jarman returned the
Chancellor.
good time of 26.3 in the 220-yard low
hurdles, defeating two C. U. competitors. Peppler ran an exciting race in
the quarter, battling neck and neck
with Hugel, of the vistors, who retained a small lead to win by a yard.
Chancellor secured a third in the
